questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office with abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient reports heavy bleeding with menstruation, soaking through more than one pad per hour for 10 days. This has been occurring every 4 weeks for the past 6 months. There is no associated fatigue, shortness of breath, or chest pain. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes, and family history is significant for Lynch syndrome. Vital signs are within normal limits. A chaperoned physical examination reveals a non-tender, enlarged, globular uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound rules out structural causes of abnormal uterine bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic study to obtain now?

choices.text: Complete blood count (CBC) and iron studies

questions.solution:
This patient, who is over 45 years of age, has abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) based on the reported volume and duration of monthly menstrual bleeding. Transvaginal ultrasound has ruled out structural causes of AUB, and the patient has risk factors for endometrial cancer (i.e., type 2 diabetes, family history of Lynch syndrome). The most appropriate next diagnostic test is an endometrial biopsy.

Endometrial biopsy is used to assess the endometrial tissue for benign glandular cells, endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN), or endometrial carcinoma. There are several ways to obtain a sample of the endometrial tissue, but the most common method is with an endometrial pipelle, which can be performed in the office. Hysteroscopy with direct biopsy of endometrial tissue can also be performed if results of a pipelle biopsy are inadequate, if a patient is unable to tolerate the office procedure, or if suspicion for EIN or endometrial carcinoma is high enough.

Endometrial biopsy is recommended for all patients who are ≥45 years of age with AUB, and for all postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness >4 mm, due to the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma. In premenopausal patients, endometrial thickness does not correlate with the risk of endometrial cancer. In patients with AUB who are under 45 years of age, biopsy is indicated if risk factors for EIN or endometrial cancer are present. These include a history of unopposed estrogen exposure, type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early age of menarche, late age of menopause, and a personal or family history of Lynch syndrome. In patients of any age with persistent AUB despite medical management, endometrial biopsy is also warranted.   

Option Analysis

✅ Endometrial biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pelvic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
Incorrect: Pelvic MRI is primarily used to further evaluate structural abnormalities such as fibroids or adenomyosis when ultrasound findings are inconclusive or in preoperative planning. In this case, transvaginal ultrasound did not reveal any structural abnormalities. Given this patient’s risk factors (i.e. family history of Lynch syndrome) for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) and endometrial cancer, an endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Complete blood count (CBC) and iron studies:
Incorrect: These tests may be useful in assessing for anemia and iron deficiency due to blood loss; however, they do not identify the underlying cause of abnormal uterine bleeding. An endometrial biopsy is the best diagnostic test to perform now.
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH):
Incorrect: TSH is part of the general workup for abnormal uterine bleeding. However, this patient's bleeding pattern and personal and family risk factors raise concern for endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) or endometrial cancer. Therefore, an endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step.
❌ Follicle stimulating hormone (FSH):
Incorrect: FSH can be used to help assess whether a patient is postmenopausal, but levels can fluctuate widely in a perimenopausal patient, making it less accurate. This patient is still having regular periods, which confirms she is not postmenopausal.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine health maintenance visit. She is in her usual state of health. Her medical history is notable for two normal vaginal deliveries, and a hysterectomy. She has no history of sexually transmitted infections and has been in a monogamous relationship for the past 10 years. She does not smoke and lives a healthy lifestyle. Her vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable. The patient asks about cervical cancer screening. Which of the following clinical factors would indicate that cervical cancer screening is not warranted for this patient?

choices.text: Total hysterectomy for leiomyomas 5 years ago
Subtotal hysterectomy for leiomyomas 5 years ago
Total hysterectomy due to cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3 years ago
Hysterectomy 5 years ago for unknown reasons
Hysterectomy 5 years ago for abnormal uterine bleeding with an unknown type of hysterectomy

questions.solution:
This patient presents for routine follow-up and asks about cervical cancer screening. If the patient underwent a total hysterectomy for leiomyomas 5 years ago, then cervical cancer screening would not be recommended.   

Cervical cancer screening is recommended for most women aged 21–65 in order to detect and manage precancerous conditions and cervical cancer in a timely manner.  The primary screening methods include the Papanicolaou (Pap) smear and human papillomavirus (HPV) testing. The former evaluates for abnormal cells, while the latter is used to detect the presence of high-risk HPV DNA. Specific guidelines dictate the frequency and type of screening based on age, previous screening history, and other risk factors.  

There are select instances where cervical cancer screening may not be warranted. This includes women who have undergone a total hysterectomy (including removal of the cervix) for benign reasons, provided they have no history of high-grade precancerous lesions or cervical cancer. Additionally, women over the age of 65 who have had adequate prior screening and are not at high risk for cervical cancer may discontinue screening. Cervical cancer screening is also not recommended for average-risk women younger than 21 years of age.  

Option Analysis

✅ Total hysterectomy for leiomyomas 5 years ago:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subtotal hysterectomy for leiomyomas 5 years ago:
Incorrect: A subtotal (also called partial or supracervical) hysterectomy involves removal of the uterus while leaving the cervix in place. Since the cervix is still present, regular cervical cancer screening according to the current guidelines is still warranted. 
❌ Total hysterectomy due to cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3 years ago:
Incorrect: Patients with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) who undergo total hysterectomy still require follow-up cancer screening typically with samples taken from the top of the vagina.
❌ Hysterectomy 5 years ago for unknown reasons:
Incorrect: Without knowing the specifics of the type of hysterectomy (whether the cervix was removed) and the reason for the surgery (benign versus malignant), recommending against cervical cancer screening is incorrect. More information would need to be obtained before screening recommendations can be made.
❌ Hysterectomy 5 years ago for abnormal uterine bleeding with an unknown type of hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Though the hysterectomy occurred for a benign reason, the presence of the cervix is not known. More information should be obtained, or an examination performed to determine if the cervix is present before screening recommendations can be made.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the gynecology office for evaluation of heavy menstrual bleeding. Her periods tend to last up to 12 days per month, and she goes through several pads per hour early in her cycle, which is difficult for her to manage at work. She often feels tired, even when not menstruating. She has no dizziness or shortness of breath. She is currently not in a monogamous relationship and is using condoms for contraception. She does not currently want to become pregnant but wants to become pregnant in the future. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg. On examination, the patient is awake and alert. Chaperoned pelvic examination is within normal limits. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a 3.4 cm solid, well-defined, submucosal uterine mass. There are no findings concerning malignancy, but it is noted on the ultrasound that the patient has a bicornuate uterus. Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin of 10.1 g/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This premenopausal patient has heavy menstrual bleeding and anemia caused by a uterine leiomyoma. Combined oral contraceptive pills would be appropriate for this patient as they would allow for preservation of future fertility, and provide current contraception.

Treatment methods for uterine leiomyoma include medical, procedural, and surgical interventions. Expectant management is an option for asymptomatic leiomyomas. When interventions are necessary or desired by the patient, things to consider include the location of the leiomyoma, current desire for pregnancy, current desire for contraception, pre or post menopausal status, desire for future pregnancies, and whether or not the treatment goal is to reduce symptoms related to tumor bulk, and/or to reduce heavy menstrual bleeding.

Medical management is typically used when the goal of treatment is to improve heavy menstrual bleeding. Medications include oral GnRH antagonists, such as elagolix and relugolix with hormonal add-back therapy to treat hypoestrogenic effects like hot flashes; the levonorgestrel intrauterine system or IUS; and contraceptive hormones, such as combined oral birth control pills, progesterone only pills and depot medroxyprogesterone. Another option for medical management is GnRH agonists, like depot leuprolide, which help decrease uterine size and bleeding and can be used as a bridge to other interventions, like surgery. When prescribing GnRH antagonists and agonists, contraception should be prescribed as indicated. Tranexamic acid may be added to medical management to help reduce bleeding.  

Procedural treatments include uterine artery embolization (UAE) which is a good option for patients who want to avoid invasive surgical interventions and desire uterine preservation. However UAE may cause permanent loss of fertility, and should be avoided in postmenopausal patients due to an increased risk of mistakenly treating a uterine sarcoma. Surgical management includes myomectomy and hysterectomy. Both can be completed with laparoscopy, robotic-assisted laparoscopy, or open techniques. Myomectomy is used for patients with submucosal leiomyomas who desire uterine preservation and/or future fertility. However, there is a risk of recurrent leiomyomas. Hysterectomy is the definitive surgical management for leiomyomas. However long-term morbidity is associated with hysterectomy with ovarian conservation including risk of early menopause, mood disorders, and cardiovascular morbidity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Combined oral contraceptive pills:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Uterine artery embolization:
Incorrect: Uterine artery embolization is an option for treating leiomyomas in premenopausal women who do not desire future fertility. It should be avoided in patients who desire a future pregnancy. Additionally, should be avoided in postmenopausal patients due to an increased risk of inadvertently treating a uterine sarcoma.  
❌ Hysterectomy:
Incorrect: Hysterectomy would not allow for future pregnancies and is associated with long-term morbidity including the risk of early menopause, mood disorders, and cardiovascular morbidity.  
❌ Levonorgestrel intrauterine system:
Incorrect: An intrauterine device (IUD) that releases levonorgestrel is an effective means of reducing heavy menstrual bleeding for patients with uterine leiomyomas. However, this patient has a bicornuate uterus, and IUDs are associated with increased rates of complications in patients with congenital uterine abnormalities.  
❌ Expectant management:
Incorrect: Expectant management is appropriate for asymptomatic leiomyomas and for symptomatic patients who do not desire intervention. This patient is experiencing significant menstrual bleeding, leading to anemia. This necessitates medical intervention.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the gynecologist’s office for evaluation of vulvar itching for three months. Over the same time, she has noticed raised areas on the skin of the vulva. She has used multiple courses of topical over-the-counter antifungal medications thinking it could be a yeast infection. However, there has been no improvement in symptoms. Past medical history is significant for a colposcopy done for abnormal cervical cytology and human papillomavirus (HPV) detected on a pap smear ten years ago. The biopsy taken from colposcopy returned cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 2 that required a loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) and more frequent pap smears. She has also been treated once for chlamydia and has a history of uterine leiomyomas. Vital signs are within normal limits. Chaperoned examination of the vulva reveals several small skin-colored raised lesions. Biopsy of the lesions shows atypical koliocytes in the upper layers of the epithelium. Which of the following is the greatest risk factor for the patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient's chronic vulvar irritation, findings of raised skin-colored vulvar lesions on exam, and atypical koliocytes on biopsy are consistent with low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL), which is a type of vulvar dysplasia. Most cases of LSIL are associated with prior HPV infection. Additional risk factors for LSIL include tobacco use and immunodeficiency.

Vulvar dysplasia includes a group of benign vulvar lesions (most commonly LSIL) and premalignant vulvar lesions (HSIL and differentiated vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia). Patients with vulvar dysplasia may experience pruritis or chronic irritation in the area. However, a sizable portion of patients are asymptomatic, and lesions are incidentally noted during examination. Abnormal pap smear cytology without a corresponding abnormality on diagnostic cervical biopsy should also prompt investigation for pathology of the vagina and vulva as these areas can be the source of the abnormal cells seen on pap smear.

Condylomata acuminata or genital warts are the most generic form of LSIL. In general, the diagnosis of condylomata acuminate can be made without a biopsy and topical medications can be started empirically. However, if patients have findings of condyloma acuminate and are postmenopausal or if the lesions do not respond to treatment, then a biopsy is needed. Biopsy of LSIL will reveal atypical koilocytes in the upper layers of the epithelium. LSILs are not precursors to cancer and should not be considered premalignant. Most LSILs are caused by HPV.

High-grade vulvar intraepithelial lesions (HSILs), however, are precancerous. HSILs are typically localized and well isolated with a raised, slightly rough texture. They are generally found on the posterior, hairless area of the vulva and perineal body, but can occur anywhere. Colposcopy findings on HSILs can include leukoplakia or hyperpigmentation, along with an atypical vascular pattern. Biopsy results will show cytologic atypia from two-thirds to full thickness of the epithelium, without invasion.

Option Analysis

✅ Prior human papilloma virus (HPV) infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Inadequate vulvar cleansing:
Incorrect: There are many over-the-counter hygiene products, including vaginal sprays, washes, douches, perfumes, and deodorants. In general, they are not recommended as they can cause significant vulvar irritation. While this patient does have vulvar irritation, her exam and biopsy findings are consistent with vulvar dysplasia, which is not caused by inadequate vulvar cleansing but can be caused by HPV infection. 
❌ History of chlamydia:
Incorrect: Chlamydia and HPV are both spread through sexual contact; however, chlamydia is not a risk factor for the development of vulvar dysplasia. HPV infection increases the risk for vulvar dysplasia.  
❌ Uterine leiomyomas:
Incorrect: Symptomatic uterine leiomyomas can cause various issues, such as heavy bleeding and pelvic pressure or pain. Leiomyomas are not associated with HPV and do not cause vulvar irritation or vulvar lesions. 
❌ Over-the-counter topical antifungal medication:
Incorrect: While some patients may experience rash as a side effect of topical antifungal medications, biopsy results of this patient’s skin lesions are consistent with vulvar dysplasia. HPV is associated with an increased risk of vulvar dysplasia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulligravid woman presents for a colposcopy exam after routine screening came back with atypical squamous cells, cannot exclude high-grade (ASC-H) and positive high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV). The patient reports that she and her partner are planning to attempt conception next year, and she is concerned about the impact of any procedures on her cervix. After patient-centered counseling, she consents to the procedures today. She is healthy and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational substances. Family history is notable for a hysterectomy in her mother due to endometrial cancer at age 60. Vital signs are normal, and a urine pregnancy test is negative. On colposcopy exam, acetic acid is applied to the cervix and abnormalities are noted surrounding the cervical os. Representative biopsies are taken and return as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient given her fertility desires?

choices.text: Observation with repeat colposcopy in 6 months

questions.solution:
This 32-year-old patient who desires future fertility is found to have cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3, which describes the presence of severely atypical cellular changes that extend through at least two thirds of the epithelial thickness (without invading through the basement membrane). It is considered an immediate precursor to cancer. Treatment is recommended and observation is considered unacceptable, even when patients are planning future pregnancies as in the vignette. This patient should have an excisional treatment like loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP).       

When treatment of high-grade dysplasia is planned, excision is preferred over ablation because the excised tissue can be assessed for unsuspected invasive cancer that may be present. It also allows for assessment of the specimen margins, which can determine whether the entire lesion was excised. Additionally, if the margins are positive, closer surveillance or retreatment is recommended. Excisional treatments include loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), cold knife conization (CKC), and laser cone biopsy. However, ablative procedures, including cryotherapy, laser ablation, and thermoablation, are acceptable alternatives when excisional procedures are unavailable.        

In contrast, close observation is appropriate for patients with CIN 2 and desire for future pregnancies and in people with high-grade cytology but only CIN 1 on biopsy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Loop electrosurgical excision procedure:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Observation with repeat colposcopy in 6 months:
Incorrect: Observation with careful surveillance is only appropriate in patients with specified CIN 2. Due to the increased risk of cancer with CIN 3, as seen in the vignette, excision procedures are recommended, even when future pregnancy is planned. 
❌ Cryotherapy:
Incorrect: With CIN 3, treatment is preferred. Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure that uses liquid nitrogen to destroy abnormal tissue. However, an excisional procedure is preferred over ablative therapy because it allows the specimen to be examined for occult disease and for disease present at the margins of the specimen. 
❌ Laser ablation:
Incorrect: With CIN 3, treatment is preferred. Laser ablation is an ablative therapy that uses lasers to destroy abnormal tissue. However, an excisional procedure is preferred over ablative therapy because it allows the specimen to be examined for occult disease and for disease present at the margins of the specimen. 
❌ Trachelectomy:
Trachelectomy refers to excision of the entire cervix. This is too invasive of a procedure for CIN-3 and would significantly increase fertility risks. A loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), cold knife conization (CKC), or laser cone biopsy is preferred.

questions.text: After completing chemotherapy, a 59-year-old woman with ovarian cancer presents to the oncology clinic for follow-up. She had been undergoing treatment with cisplatin. She had experienced significant nausea and vomiting throughout the treatment course, controlled with ondansetron. The patient has also experienced increased hair loss since undergoing treatment. What is the mechanism by which cisplatin acts as a chemotherapeutic agent?

choices.text: Cross-linking of adjacent guanine nucleotides in DNA

questions.solution:
Platinum-containing chemotherapeutic agents include cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin. These agents inhibit DNA repair and replication by cross-linking adjacent guanines, preventing the DNA strands from being separated.    

The type of DNA repair that occurs depends on if the damage is single or double-stranded.    

Single-strand repair is accomplished via nucleotide, base excision, and mismatch repair. In nucleotide excision repair, specific endonucleases excise oligonucleotides that contain a pyrimidine dimer. A base-specific glycosylase removes the damaged base, subsequently filled in by DNA polymerase in base excision repair. In mismatch repair, mismatched bases in a new unmethylated DNA strand are excised.  

On the other hand, double-strand repair occurs through non-homologous end-joining or homologous recombination. Non-homologous end-joining involves reattaching the ends of 2 DNA fragments that may not be homologous. This process causes loss of DNA and thus a higher rate of mutation. Homologous recombination requires two homologous DNA duplexes to occur. There is no loss of nucleotides, so the integrity of the DNA is better maintained.    

Platinum-containing compounds are cell phase nonspecific and have the potential to inhibit both single-strand and double-strand repair.   

Option Analysis

✅ Cross-linking of adjacent guanine nucleotides in DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Formation of thymine dimers:
Incorrect: These are covalent linkages induced by exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation. In contrast, cisplatin works by cross-linking two adjacent guanines, thus preventing DNA repair and replication.   
❌ Double-strand breakages:
Incorrect: These types of breaks are induced by ionizing radiation. They are deliberately induced during meiosis I to allow for homologous recombination. Cisplatin works via a different mechanism of action.   
❌ Inhibition of deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP) production:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) acts as a chemotherapeutic agent. 5-FU is used to treat various malignancies, including gastrointestinal, breast, and cervical carcinomas. dTMP is used in DNA repair and replication, so cells cannot survive without it.   
❌ Stabilization of topoisomerase II:
Incorrect: This choice describes the mechanism of action of doxorubicin causing cytotoxicity. Doxorubicin is used in the treatment of malignancies. Topoisomerase breaks the DNA chain for replication, but doxorubicin stabilizes it and prevents the double helix from being resealed.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a follow-up of an abnormal cervical cancer screen. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge. She has kept up with cervical cancer screening in the past and has not had abnormal results previously. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She has never been pregnant and has no history of sexually transmitted infections. She has no significant medical history and takes no medication. She does not smoke and consumes alcohol socially. Her family history is noncontributory. Her pelvic examination at the last visit was normal. Her cytology shows abnormal cells, and she has a negative human papillomavirus (HPV) test. The immediate CIN3+ risk is calculated to be < 4%, and the 5-year CIN 3+ risk is calculated to be 0.2%. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after an abnormal Pap smear, which reveals atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US), and a negative high-risk HPV test. Her immediate CIN3+ risk is <4% and her 5-year risk for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) 3+ is relatively low, at 0.2%. The most appropriate surveillance strategy is repeat high-risk HPV testing in 3 years.   

Surveillance strategies for abnormal cervical cancer screening results are increasingly guided by the 5-year risk of CIN 3+. CIN refers to the precancerous changes in the cells lining the cervix, and it is categorized into three grades based on the severity of these changes. CIN 1 is considered low-grade, while CIN 2 and CIN 3 are high-grade, with CIN 3 being the most severe and the most likely to progress to cervical cancer if left untreated.  

This risk stratification model helps to tailor patient care, ensuring that women with higher risk (CIN 3+ risk ≥ 4%) receive immediate and intensive investigation and management, such as colposcopy and biopsy. In contrast, for those with lower risk (< 4%), a more conservative approach is appropriate with monitoring with repeat testing at designated intervals. This strategy aims not only to identify and treat high-grade lesions promptly but also to reduce over-testing and overtreatment of conditions that are unlikely to progress to cancer.  

Patients with CIN 3+ risk < 0.15%, with a negative history of abnormal screenings, may undergo cytology alone every 3 years, or HPV-based testing every 5 years. If the 5-year CIN 3+ risk is between 0.15% and 0.54%, patients should undergo 3-year surveillance with HPV-based testing. If the 5-year CIN3+ risk is between 0.55% and 3.99%, patients should undergo 1-year surveillance, with HPV-based testing. 

Option Analysis

✅ Repeat HPV testing in 3 years:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repeat Pap smear in 1 year:
Incorrect: A repeat Pap smear in 1 year is not the recommended surveillance strategy for this patient with a 5-year CIN3+ risk of only 0.2%. Testing with repeat pap smears in 1 year could lead to over-testing and increase patient anxiety without providing significant additional benefit.
❌ Repeat HPV testing in 5 years:
Incorrect: This would be an appropriate screening strategy for a patient without an abnormal pap smear cytology result or for a patient with an abnormal pap smear result and CIN 3+ risk < 0.15%. Closer surveillance is recommended for this patient.
❌ Repeat HPV testing in 1 year:
Incorrect: Repeat HPV testing in 1 year is not the recommended surveillance strategy for this patient with a 5-year CIN3+ risk of only 0.2%. This patient should have repeat HPV testing in 3 years.
❌ Immediate colposcopy:
Incorrect: Colposcopy is reserved for higher-risk abnormalities or when there is a positive high-risk HPV test. This patient has a negative HPV test and a low 5-year CIN3+ risk. Therefore, immediate colposcopy would be considered overtreatment and could result in unnecessary anxiety and potential harm without clear benefit.
